text:
Hello Superpath community!

We have a new "Dear Superpath" question. This is a way for folks to ask anonymous questions. 

Career stage: mid (4-7 years of experience)

"Hi all,

I'm currently looking to transition out of agency life. I have about four years of content experience all together, but I'm having a hard time finding positions for mid-level content marketers. 

When I look at job boards, I see tons of junior content writer positions and plenty of senior content marketing manager positions but very few positions for people of my experience level. The former pay way below what I make now and the latter require ~8+ years of experience. 

Does anyone have advice for finding mid-level positions or otherwise building my skills up?"

I'd say just go for the high-level ones.

Content is poorly understood by lots of companies, and I'd wager that a good chunk of the "8+" postings were forged with a lot of wiggle room. Position your agency experience as a big, juicy bonus multiplier—lots of content makers out there may be freelance/solo/coming from other worlds.

Also, the time before you were at agency: did you post on social media? That' experience. Or did you do content creation outside of work with at the agency? 2x experience right there.

This risk, of course, is if a company hasn't really got a good grasp of what a senior content marketing person actually is, you may end up in a dysfunctional role, be an island, etc. But for the quantum career leap, that may be an acceptable level of risk.

text:
hello all - a little Sunday career advice request from me :slightly_smiling_face: (apologies if this gets really long!) I’m a former journalist and current content marketer working in B2B tech in London, UK.

I’ve had a few crappy experiences in the past 9 months or so:
• I left a brilliant-company-gone-bad to join an emerging mental health startup, only to find that the role was totally the wrong fit for me (mainly social media-based) as it developed.
• I left that one to join another role at a consultancy tech company that helps orgs in the public sector modernise their services. Writing in this sector sucked the passion from me, big time. I stopped sleeping, became super anxious about work and was pretty miserable.
I’m (un?)lucky in that I need to be interested/engaged in what I do. So, I started looking into freelancing, and I already have a great client - an emerging HR tech start-up.

I resigned my job to freelance full-time - and fully started leaning into it.

On Friday this week, I was offered a full-time senior job at a great start-up with a £10k pay rise, and it absolutely blindsided me.

I know that I’ve been extremely lucky to have these experiences in what has been quite a tough time for everyone… But now I’m faced with a huge quandary. Does anyone have any insight or experience they’d like to share with me? Any insight on the freelance environment? I’d so appreciate it. Thank you! :relaxed:

text:
Hi. Can you freelance on the side? That is the best way to feed your internal desire for new and interesting projects while also having a secure  job where you are a part of something bigger. Most full-time gigs lose their magic over time no matter how exciting they seem. It's nice to have that side project to keep you sharp. The best part of having a secure job is you pick and choose side projects you care about.

My experience as a 100% freelancer is that it's a constant hustle. Things can be great now, but projects slow down and the chances of the next project aligning with your passions are slim. Another possibility is to work out a long-term contract with your current freelance client if they are willing. Just some random Sunday thoughts. Good luck.

<@U01H58AMEAD> thanks so much for the reply - these are all great random Sunday thoughts!

I definitely could freelance on the side of full-time work. My current freelance contract is if not long-term, then for the foreseeable future, and it’s quite a no-pressure arrangement so I’d be free to flex/back off as necessary if work got too busy :thumbsup:

I think you hit the nail on the head with desire for new things vs being part of something. It does feel like they’re in opposition, but maybe they don’t have to be! Thanks so much for the advice :slightly_smiling_face:
